												FlatOut 2 came out just 2 years after its predecessor and was released in June 2006. That would make it around the time when I actually first played the game with my friends. Man, the game was good. Recently I have decided to try it out again, and to my surprise the game still rocks! 


FlatOut 2 | How to play online without LAN. 
A Guide for FlatOut 2
By: TUYmerik

			How to play online without any LAN emulators like hamachi, tunngle etc.		


FlatOut 2 is by far the best racing game of it's kind that I have played. Long time has passed since the release, but everything about the game still seems really good from graphics to gameplay. Unfortunately there's no online but LAN via other software is possible. Do not fret though, single player is extremely fun. The AI is scripted very well. By the end of 2-3 cups you will understand how every individual AI drives. They don't always want to win now, some of them want to crash others players cars. It does not mean that it will always be you though. So expect some random stuff happen to you during the game. Never under estimate the opponent. 


Holy cow this is gonna be bad! 
A Screenshot of FlatOut 2
By: Princess Gay X




The  soundtrack just blew my mind. I do like the type of music that this game has, but to think that I know almost all of the songs in the game just makes it so much better. This game has lots of big names  like Rob Zombie, Wolfmother and .... Nickleback. But what's more important is that the car engine sound like a boss, the noise is so sexy, sometimes I just lower the music volume. 


Sexy beast 
A Screenshot of FlatOut 2
By: Princess Gay X




It been almost 9 years now, but the graphics will not hurt your eye, in fact this game probably eclipsed a ton of racing games which came out around the same time. Car details are very good, both brand new and half destroyed. The maps look just awesome, textures still look good to this day. Human ragdolls are a bit on the downside again, but you do not tend to fly out as often anymore. Overall, I am extremely happy about the graphics and how they are still so good even eight years after. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351276072What else is important about the racing game for PC players, a game that was also realsead on consoles? The answer is controls. Finally, I played a game, where you can easily steer just by using your arrows on the keyboard. Game is very playable without a joystick. It also feels that the developers made it easier to control cars in the first place. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351276142By now your thinking that there must be something bad about the game. Well, I am going to tell you that there are non big things that will off put you. There are minor things about interacting with physical objects, but that's about it guys, this game is almost perfect! http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351137260Replayabilty is massive, once you discover the LAN. To conclude, this game deserves the price. If there's no sale then just buy it. You will not regret it. The game is so good, you will end up driving at least for the next 5 hours before taking a break.

												FlatOut 2 is an absolute get! I can't recommend it enough!I was dying for a new racing game to play and happened to have a few bucks in my Steam wallet from selling cards and on a whim bought it for a mere $2.49! Which was an out right steal for this game. If I had known how fun this was I would of gotten it sooner, its regular $10 asking price is still a steal for this!Fun:• Slamming into people feels nice, heavy and like you're really doing some damage to'em.• It has variety in spades. Be it flinging your driver across water, through burning hoops or for playing poker. Demolition derbies, short simple circuit tracks and the varied longer race courses, theres a lot here.• The sound design is astoundingly good. It has probably the best tire squeals I've ever heard in a racing game. Most games have 1 long squeal which sounds more like the car is doing a burn out than struggling to maintain grip. In this it has a nice stutter to it, like it really is struggling and about to give. You can hear rocks knocking around your wheel well and under your car on the dirt tracks, something I notice games overlook a bit.• The cars are a great. With a heavy focus on muscle cars for the most part, which is great cause I lost my taste for racing games when they suddenly became mostly about nasty little rice burners (looking at you Need for Speed.). Cheat codes.Meh:• The soundtrack is just well.. meh. At no point will there ever not be a guitar or drum playing. It tends to get a little grating to listen to near constant noise. 												One of the best arcade/vehicular combat racing games ever. More about high speed and destroying all the decorations, rather than Flatout 1 where the tracks have more tricky cornering and where you had to pick which objects to collide with. What I like:-Nice looking cars, they are based on real life models suitably. Though the models are somewhat low-poly strangely, Flatout 1 has more detailed models..-Pretty okay graphics still overall although NFS Most Wanted from 2004 for example already had more advanced things regarding textures, shaders and lighting system..I mean, FO2 doesn't have bump mapping, not all shadows in FO2 are realtime shadows and no realtime reflections either..yet FO2 has sharp textures in comparison for one.-Good sound design, the cars..although they kinda lack volume and intensity..FO1 had more intense engine noises. Ultimate carnage corrected the problem by having a clipping distortion effect for the player's engine noise, it made the fo2 sounds more aggressive suitably. The sound of small rocks in gravel roads pinging and ricocheting in the wheel wells is remarkably awesome and lovely to hear, makes the countryside tracks all the better to race in. Good crash sfx, when you crash subtly versus hard the difference is plenty audible :) although there could have been more crunching metal and stressing metal type sounds.-Handling physics, there is clearly difference between all the drive types. Though there could have been some handling nuances for some cars..aside of their grippiness rating, there is no other differentiation for the handling between cars.-The gameplay. Cathartic. You race with cars of 3 different type, derby cars which are beat up, slow yet durable old cars. Then race cars, something alike to scuffed and worn rally cars, they are 80's-00's era cars with moderate top speeds and acceleration, and mid range toughness. And lastly the street class with import tuners and muscle cars, these sleds are devilishly fast but lack in durability overall, made worse by crashes in that class being usually on high speeds :d There is the usual circuit races and to complement those there are the derbies where the one with most collective score from damaging opponents wins..not necessarily last man standing wins, the special event races such as a oval gravel track, figure of eight and some others. Lastly there is the silly stunts, where you throw your driver out of the windshield, for example to stick to a wall in high jump to score the best height. In all races but stunts, there will be crashing..often indirect crashing too, from pushing your opponent to an obstacle.What I don't like..No choice to have the bloom off yet the other post processing effects on. The bloom doesn't help to make an upbeat atmosphere, rather it is obtrusive and blinding..no idea how I back then played FO2 with the post processing on.8.5/10.

												Even though Steam says I have not a lot of hours played for this game don't be fooled! I have played this game long before I even joined Steam and all I can say is that FlatOut 2 is one of the best derby games out there.Pros:- Great Soundtrack: In my opinion, the majority of the soundtrack is epic that'll put you right in the racing mood.- Replay Value: No joke, this game has so much variety it'll take a long long time before you'll get bored. From races to derby matches to even stunts, it seems endless. For example, you may have a Single Player race in the forest lands. Well there are 3 maps of forest or so to chose from. This applies to everything in Single Races, like racing in the city or racing on a track.- It's Hilarious: If you crash your car at a certain angle your driver ejects out as a ragdoll. It's just hilarious. The stunts involve ragdolls as well, which makes the stunt aspect challenging as you can move your ragdoll in the air- or give it a little 'nudge' to go farther or higher.- Handling: The steering isn't too hard. Playing with the keyboard isn't too difficult to manage. if you get used to it, you can go off with a victory without using a gamepad.- "Realistic": In moderation, of course. You can lose a wheel and driving the car becomes more challenging. If you use a 'street' car in the forest the handling won't be so easy. Pieces fly off your car, doors fall off, windows break, muffles unhinge, it's a joy ride if you love crashes!Cons:- Since the world on the race track is practically destroyable in every way some things can cost you a first place finish. 												While the first game was hard FlatOut 2 is beyond easy & hard. It is arbitrary, luck decides if you win or not and you as the player have little influence on that.There are two main issuesThe engine/the car behaviorYou cannot predict how your car will react during a jump or hitting an obstacle. Sometimes it runs smoothly, sometimes you will lose your position or advantage. Therefore there is little space in getting better or master the game, because you don't get proper feedback which action benefits you and which one will be punished.You will find at the bottom a video I've done about two stunts. The only thing I do is pressing throttle without pausing it, so there is no room for variation. I do this in both stunts. Two exact same actions from the player result in different outcomings.The AI/your opponentsSome of them are trolls, not interested in winning the race just ramming other cars and putting themselves at the tail end while giving you a hard time.The other extreme are the flawless ones, usually using one of the higher level cars which you have to unlock first. Catching up with them happens rarely. They usually drive clean and boost forwards if you are getting close. Starting at the last position puts you in huge disadvantage against those.The other thing is that the AI adapts to you. Are you driving faster or have you upgraded your car? They get better as well, so the difficulty seems to stay stable. At least to a certain point. Buying a new car with much better values makes the races easier, but not as much as I expected.Some small annoyances-The starting position varies, but most times I got the last place or something near that.-Later in the game you may have to repeat races a couple times to collect the amount of money to buy a car you've just unlocked. Winning all level 1 races doesn't guarantee you having enough money for a Level 2 car.-Strangely a Level 1 car isn't necessary good enough to compete in Level 1 races. I once had to grind for a better one and repeated the races.-NPCs get fixed cars from the start of a class and some of them get ones from a higher tier. It would be fairer if everyone would use a car from the same level.All in all: Driving good doesn't get rewarded, you need a certain amount of luck. Both, losses and victories, felt cheap and latter one never satisfied me. I was just relieved to be over the current race.Now the most important point:Does this all make the game unenjoyable? It depends.Are you looking for a serious racing game? Is anything but 1st place not an option to you? Then skip this one. It started pretty easy and was fun, but the further I got into the game the more the races turned into bitter and teeth-gnashing hours of retries which felt more like playing roulette and waiting untill the ball hits your number.If you don't care about the mentioned issues, because just beating the game is enough for you or you just want to have a bit random wanky car physics fun, you might wanna try it. At least it won't hurt as long as you don't take it too seriously and bite your teeth into it.Video:

												My first instinct is to put a NO on recommending this game. That's because it's so often infuriating.The racing here is all about physics and destruction. You can crash into the scenery and your fellow racers, resulting in detailed and wild destruction.This is what makes the game both fun and frustrating. More often than not, finishing in first place is a matter of blind luck, thanks to all the scattered debris all over the tracks. I mean ALL over everywhere. The slightest bump will send you careening off into the side of the track. Same if you get bumped by a fellow racer.That's basically my only gripe with the game. Otherwise it's tons of fun. The damage model on the cars and environment is pretty great (I know, I was just complaining about them!) The career mode is nice and simple, varied, with a great selection of tracks and game modes and cars.Each car can also be upgraded in various ways. You could focus on speed and just go for the finish. You could focus on strength and make your car a high powered ram rod, disabling the competition.There's also the stunt levels where the already-filmsy realism is flung out through the windshield, just like your driver will be, flying into bowling pins or a velcro wall for points. Very silly, very difficult (at least for me), very fun.I haven't played other FlatOut games. People say this one is the best of the series. Check out the spiritual sequel, "Wreckfest / Next Car Game", here on Steam.

Make the Ravioli dough.- Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix.- Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed.- Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough.- Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic.- Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters.- With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles).- Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Fill the Ravioli shells.- Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough.- Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle.- Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a “homemade” touch as well.- Repeat this process for all your dough circles.- Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together. Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker.- Roll the dough into two sheets- Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups.- Fill with the ravioli mixture.- Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling.- Remove and separate the finished raviolis.Cook the Ravioli.- Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil.- Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test.- If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest - Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed platesServe it up.Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy!

												Though this game gets a lot of praise it has some glaring flaws that you should be aware of, I'll touch on the good points first:*The car destruction looks very realistic, and you'll notice actual changes in handing as your car accrues more damage; when your car is badly damaged for example it will lose a wheel and handling will become a nightmare.*There are a wide variety of off and on-road environments to race on, from deserts, to cities, to forests, as well as some fun mini-games to add replay value. The named opponents and different driving styles also add some personality to the career mode.---However on the whole this game left me more frustrated than entralled, so now I'll get to the bad news:The handling in this game is just bad, to the point that it feels like you're driving a hovercraft rather than a car, and a single shunt or slight oversteer can sent you off the track into a wall. This is also counter-intuitive to the design of the game since you're encouraged to drive aggressive and crash into things, but when the margin for error is so high it's usually safer to avoid taking jumps or smashing into traffic lights.The single-player mode relies on the catch-up effect to prevent a single spinout from taking you out of the race, but in the (now-defunct) online multiplayer this is nonexistent - meaning a single oversteer or ram from an opponent in the first minute of the race can take you out, which is frustrating rather than fun in an acade racer.Aside from that, the game's musical score feels out of place for a destruction-oriented racing game, consisting mainly of pop punk, emo, and alternative rock tracks - it seems to have taken a cue from the Burnout series here. The graphics are also a little too bright and cheerful for my taste.The final notable flaw is the unbalanced cars. The game is divided into 3 classes of cars, and each class has 1 or 2 high-end cars which are far-and-away superior in every respect to the others in their class. In multiplayer this means that nearly everyone will just end up driving the same car in every race, while the others just go unused.While this isn't a terrible game, on the whole I consider it overhyped and overrated; though the single-player mode may offer a casual racing diversion to some.

The Good:-Good destructive fun-Much more content than FlatOut 1 with Race and Street mode, with lots of new Events.The Bad:-There are too many forks/alternate routes that lead to manufactured collisions compared to FlatOut 1.-The destruction overall is much more manufactured than FlatOut 1. In FlatOut 1 most of the clutter came from tyres from tyre walls, in FlatOut 2 you have all kinds of clutter that obscure the view of the track. Most of the clutter also has 'weight' which means that if you drive into it then you'll collide with it instead of just driving over it or through it. This normally wouldn't be so bad, but because there is so much clutter it usually covers the width of the track so you have no choice but to collide into it. Driving in 1st person mode it can get very tricky when this clutter attaches itself to the bonnet of the car, obscuring your entire view and making you have to change camera. That's just poor design.The game has partial controller support with the racing being fine with the gamepad but the menus are only navigational with a keyboard.Overall it's not a bad game, if you haven't played FlatOut 1. FlatOut 2 has more content, but I much preferred the track design and organic destruction of FlatOut 1.

												Flatout 2 has the same developer and publisher as the first game; and yet, somehow, they've managed to make it feel like a cheap Flatout ripoff.The innovative damage and driving system of the first game is gone, replaced with arcade style physics instead. Missing as well, is unlocking the entire tier of cars in one go, rather having to unlock individual cars as you compete, entirely precluding you from being able to save up for the car you want, and carry it through the tier with you, as with the previous game. Vehicle upgrades are also severely limited when compared to the first game as well, with only one tier for each upgrade, and many upgrades from the previous game being entirely absent. All the vehicles more or less handle the same, despite this game having differences between FWD, 4WD, and RWD cars, with weight and strength not coming into play at all with the exception of during derby events.Level design makes no logical sense, with entire structures appearing and disappearing with track layouts that are supposed to be in the same location. All the tracks feel as though they were designed as race tracks first, and the copy and pasted into the game's various locals, rather than designed from the ground up to suit that location. As a result, all of the tracks feel more or less the same, with different scenery adorning each one, rather than different and unique challenging locations.Gone as well is the previous game's unique soundtrack, replaced with generic pop and rock music. While I have nothing against the songs themselves, they take away from the "country and backwoods" feel of a derby-style racing game, and replace it with something that feels like it belongs in Need For Speed: Underground.All and all, I cannot recommend this game. It is held aloft almost entirely on the success of its predecessor, but with about half the production budget. I recommend buying the first game, and forgetting this travesty ever existed.

												 "An extreme classic which is a fast loading time consumer where you never have a clean race."Quite simply; Burnout with character. Burnout is all about crashing at speed, whilst Flatout 2 is much about racing with anyway possible. Whether it's smashing the opposition into trees or smashing through shops to gain nitro, every race is different, fun and action packed.If you enjoy burnout and/or Flatout, then this is perfect. Although Flatout based around 70's American muscle derby racing, Flatout 2 expands into tuner and exotic classes and even a school bus (best vehicle in the game). This gives it more variety and a more satisfying time. Of course, being a Flatout game, the bonus games are as silly and unique as before. Only this time the stunt cars have the minor addition of jet engines. There is also a character system, which tells you who is ahead and who you just T-boned off into a river. This can cause serious grudge matches and is useful for long championships. Overall, this game is simply an expansion of Flatout, with twice the destruction, twice the action, and of course, twice the fun.

												I'm not a fan of racing games, but FlatOut 2 is one of my favourite games ever. Here's why I love it:- The graphics might be outdated for some, but I'm still in love with the sunsets in some of the tracks.- I'm pretty sure, you've seen better physics since this game came out, but boy, is it fun to run over a bench in the park at full throttle, rocketing inthrough the air, while spinning like the devil's wheel and landing in first place, smashing someone else's car to pieces.- Lots of people ♥♥♥♥♥ about the rock music chosen for the game, but they can go and buy another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ racing game, because all of them are the same with techno, hip-hop and rap music. Finally a game that is an exception. Okay, I might be a bit biased, because if you look into my mp3 player you'll find most of the bands that have gotten into this game. Some examples: Rise Against, Rob Zombie, Fall Out Boy, Yellowcard, Papa Roach, Audioslave and yes, Nickelback (but none of the cheesy songs), among others.- Yes, most of the maps return in the game, but they'll be different in playstyle because you'll have a different car as well as your opponents. Where you could speed up earlier and smash into something, later on in the game, you'll probably have to avoid, because the races get faster and the cars less durable. I know every map by heart and still cannot stop playing this game.- I did not care much about the mini-games, where you have to smash your driver out of the car through the window, but that's just me, it was still really funny with some friends gathered around.- I promise, you won't find any other racing game in which smashing into an opponents car is as satisfying as in this one. You can see the damage you've done, and if you want to, you can destroy  any opponent's car, so they don't get much points during the racing events. Count your points, win the first three races of the event and spend the last race wrecking all the other racers (you'll get to like some of the AI racers, and you'll grow to hate others, I for one hate Sofia Martinez with a burning passion :P ). Oh, and did I mention you get money for the destruction you cause?  So, if you are bored to death by all the neon and hip-hop filled games in which you cannot damage your car, this one's for you! Try it, buy it, love it! :)

												Here it is, the sequel to a timeless classic, but is it better or worse? Well, a large majority will likely say the former, while looking through a pair of rose-tinted Nostalgia-brand glasses.Me? not so much.There are some big improvements over Flatout 1, but some problems have been made significantly worse. First, lets start with the driving.DRIVING:The driving feels overall pretty solid and nice, arcadey, but not to the extent of say, need for speed. Its sort of a blend of realistic behavor with physics breaking abilities. So far, its pretty good. Front-wheel drive cars tend to understeer into corners, rear-wheel drive tends to slide around more, oversteering, and 4WD is a bit of both, mostly understeer though. All well and good and as it should be. However Sometimes it can be very very unpredictable. Sometimes when landing a jump, your car will smash into the ground, either bouncing into the air or veering to the left or right, causing you to wreck, sometimes your car will completly flip upon landing a jump. THis all depends on the car, but really it can be complete luck weather you land a jump and keep going or crash and have to restart the race, which you will be doing, ALOT.Next, the tracksTRACKS:Oh, dear lord did they mess this one up badly.You know that thing i said in my Flatout 1 review?Originally posted by Spitfiredwod:Some objects are badly placed on tracks, like excavators,trucks,tractors ect all being placed in bad areas, wich can cause unneeded or undeserved wrecks, it also makes it harder to get a good driving line through certain corners. Sometimes even the tinest of objects like cones, can cause huge wrecks too. Yeah, well imagine that, only about ten-thousand times worse.Holy moly did they go overboard on the smashable props! It wouldnt really even be so much of a problem, if said props dissapeared or became uncollideable after being smashed into, but, no.The props just go everywhere, all over the track at critical points before turns or after jumps, and ALL of them will cause you to wreck, every single one, even the cardboard boxes.These props are everywhere, on every track in the game, and they are nearly impossible to avoid.Id say, out of the hundreds of wrecks that ive had in the game so far, 98% of them have not been my fault, 78% is likely due to the props, and at least 20% are due to the bad AI, which we'll get to later.Not to mention, the unbreakable solid objects badly placed on the edges of the track are still here, though, they are usually just boulders instead of trucks or diggers. However they are all pretty much completely hidden by grass, you wont know its there until you've hit one, and half the time you'll be saying "What the f**k did i just hit?" as you restart your race for the 17th time in a row, and no, thats not and exaggeration.THE AI:Im just going to be blunt here.This game has the worst AI rubberbanding ive ever seen in a racing game, ive been playing racing games for 12 years, many have had AI rubberbanding, but this one tops them all.To give a little explanation on this, ill use Gran Turismo 1/ Gran Turismo 2 for example, games nutorious for having AI rubberbanding.In GT1 and GT2 The AI would speed up or slow down depending on how much you were beating them, or them beating you. THis is used in an attempt to keep the racing close and fair.If you got 2 seconds a lap ahead, the AI would speed up a bit, usually matching your speed, your able to stay out in front, but if you make a really bad turn or crash, they will catch back up, or pass you. If your in a really fast car, you can outrun the speed boost. The same thing applies if your being beaten, the AI cars slow down by 2 seconds, giving you a chance to catch up, or pass them if you wrecked.Thats essentially what its like here, only its done way, way worse.Instead of your cars being equally matched, In street class, the AI cars will be almost twice as fast as your car, no matter what car it is or if its fully upgraded. The race starts and your left in the dust. then they brake a bit, allowing you to pass, only to smash you to bits or fly right past you once again.Basically, it doesnt matter how good of a driver you are, no amount of perfect driving lines or well timed boosts is going to give you an edge. The AI is basically there to stomp you, and you have to either get out in front and drive nearly perfect to stay there, which due to the AIs speed, wont last long, Or you and try and smash everyone who gets near you to peices. Either way, its racing hell.Finally, the multiplayer.MULTIPLAYER:The multiplayer is where the real fun lies. No garbage AI to ruin your day here, and usually less props get involved, due to  less people smashing into them. (though some are unaviodable and automatic, like the rock slide on Pinegrove.)The game has, or, had real online multiplayer, which was a huge plus over Flatout 1. However in late 2012 rumors that GameSpy, the company responsible for Hosting Flatout 2's online servers, and many many other games , would be shutting down. This would sadly prove true, as on May 31st 2013, Gamespy shut its doors for good, and took all of its servers with it..However, its not all bad, nowadays you can use many different programs to play GameSpy hosted games online, Flatout included. The multiplayer on Flatout 2 is very fun, you can race with, or smash other real players to bits. You can host lobbies with up to 8 players. As a host, you can change what tracks will be raced, what derbies or events will take place, what cars players will be able to use, how many laps a race will have, and so on.  Theres also text, and voice chat in lobbies. Ive never seen anyone using a microphone though, so i cant really answer to the quality of voice chat.OTHER STUFF;The Soundtrack here is pretty great, aside from the 2 Nickelback songs that is. Theres songs from, and not limited to:MegadethPapa RoachFall Out BoyRise AgainstWolfmotherRob ZombieThere havent been any really noticable bugs in what ive seen so far, aside from one minor glitch, where you can drive through a wall on a City track, however the glitch is useless, and wont give you a competitive edge.OVERALL;While i do reccomend this, because it can be quite fun, its also very frustrating at times. Be prepared to restart races 10-15 times to win.7/10.

												I'm not a fan of racing games, but FlatOut 2 is one of my favourite games ever. Here's why I love it:- The graphics might be outdated for some, but I'm still in love with the sunsets in some of the tracks.- I'm pretty sure, you've seen better physics since this game came out, but boy, is it fun to run over a bench in the park at full throttle, rocketing inthrough the air, while spinning like the devil's wheel and landing in first place, smashing someone else's car to pieces.- Lots of people ♥♥♥♥♥ about the rock music chosen for the game, but they can go and buy another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ racing game, because all of them are the same with techno, hip-hop and rap music. Finally a game that is an exception. Okay, I might be a bit biased, because if you look into my mp3 player you'll find most of the bands that have gotten into this game. Some examples: Rise Against, Rob Zombie, Fall Out Boy, Yellowcard, Papa Roach, Audioslave and yes, Nickelback (but none of the cheesy songs), among others.- Yes, most of the maps return in the game, but they'll be different in playstyle because you'll have a different car as well as your opponents. Where you could speed up earlier and smash into something, later on in the game, you'll probably have to avoid, because the races get faster and the cars less durable. I know every map by heart and still cannot stop playing this game.- I did not care much about the mini-games, where you have to smash your driver out of the car through the window, but that's just me, it was still really funny with some friends gathered around.- I promise, you won't find any other racing game in which smashing into an opponents car is as satisfying as in this one. You can see the damage you've done, and if you want to, you can destroy  any opponent's car, so they don't get much points during the racing events. Count your points, win the first three races of the event and spend the last race wrecking all the other racers (you'll get to like some of the AI racers, and you'll grow to hate others, I for one hate Sofia Martinez with a burning passion :P ). Oh, and did I mention you get money for the destruction you cause?  So, if you are bored to death by all the neon and hip-hop filled games in which you cannot damage your car, this one's for you! Try it, buy it, love it! :)

												TL;DR - If you like arcade racers, you'll love this. Just buy it already.There are 3 classes of vehicles: derby, race and street. The career mode has you starting out with the derby class, earning money by doing well in races. You buy a vehicle, upgrade the vehicle and you can buy more vehicles if you want to change cars depending on the track. There are no power-ups or other BS like that, which is a great thing IMO.In my mind, this racing in this game is mostly about trying to screw over your opponents and avoiding danger. You may start to develop a bit of a rivalry with the AI. Nothing feels quite as satisfying as performing a PIT maneuver on JASON WALKER, THAT OVERPOWERED PIECE OF ♥♥♥♥. That said, it should be noted that the races are a bit easy to begin with and there's no real way to make it more difficult other than getting to the race/street classes.As well as races there are special 'events' such as bowling, darts and football/soccer. These mostly just involve flinging your driver at high speeds into something. These are extremely entertaining, but good luck winning 1st place!For the most part, the physics feel pretty solid. For some reason the handling feels weird with the chase cameras, so I would recommend using the 1st person or nose camera (if that's what they're called).I use a wired Xbox 360 controller to play this. Unfortunately you have to navigate the menus using the keyboard.The soundtrack is pretty darn good; I'd suggest looking it up. It's nice to have some old favourites to listen to, although it may start to get repetitive after a while.While there are some minor annoyances/issues, this is still my favourite arcade racer ever.

												I had the original Flatout for PS2, and while the 2nd one is better in its racing and derby, I definitely remember while I stopped playing after a while. The first FO had better mini games, even though I don't think they gave you any money/credits for winning like this one does. The variety of games is nice though, even if the high-jump now has ridiculous new requirements and obstacles in order to actually post a score xPFlatout has always had really random physics. You can run over some fences and cones, but hit a box and suddenly it gets underneath you and you're suddenly facing the wrong way? And everything will turn you the wrong way! I flipped end over end for a good 100 yds, spinning around twice on my trunk, and without fail landed facing the wrong direction. Every single time! The walls and barriers have magnets in them too, so all the metal in the front of your car instantly finds the nearest one and is plastered there - unless heaven forbid you hit the brakes and The racing from 'derby' through the 'racing' class is fun, even though the tracks get old. Once you hit 'street', prepared to be  ♥♥♥♥♥♥. As the cars get lower, everything will mess you up as it gets under the car - which makes sense. But what doesn't is the seemingly nothingness that will send you spiraling out of control. "Ohp, you hit a small bump; better not over-correct and face the wrong way!"The street class upgrades are a joke too. 4300cr for .1 handling!? Really?!All in all, a fun game and infinitely better than Flatout 3! Best to only do a little bit of the 'street' class and just max out 'derby' and 'race' to keep the game at max fun - and do demo derbys! You get really adament about smashing your most hated rival, lol.

												TL;DR - If you like arcade racers, you'll love this. Just buy it already.There are 3 classes of vehicles: derby, race and street. The career mode has you starting out with the derby class, earning money by doing well in races. You buy a vehicle, upgrade the vehicle and you can buy more vehicles if you want to change cars depending on the track. There are no power-ups or other BS like that, which is a great thing IMO.In my mind, this racing in this game is mostly about trying to screw over your opponents and avoiding danger. You may start to develop a bit of a rivalry with the AI. Nothing feels quite as satisfying as performing a PIT maneuver on JASON WALKER, THAT OVERPOWERED PIECE OF ♥♥♥♥. That said, it should be noted that the races are a bit easy to begin with and there's no real way to make it more difficult other than getting to the race/street classes.As well as races there are special 'events' such as bowling, darts and football/soccer. These mostly just involve flinging your driver at high speeds into something. These are extremely entertaining, but good luck winning 1st place!For the most part, the physics feel pretty solid. For some reason the handling feels weird with the chase cameras, so I would recommend using the 1st person or nose camera (if that's what they're called).I use a wired Xbox 360 controller to play this. Unfortunately you have to navigate the menus using the keyboard.The soundtrack is pretty darn good; I'd suggest looking it up. It's nice to have some old favourites to listen to, although it may start to get repetitive after a while.While there are some minor annoyances/issues, this is still my favourite arcade racer ever.
